{{lang|ar|عبدالرشيد }} |image = File:Kj%27j.jpg#/media/File:Kj%27j.jpg |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1964|1|29}} | birth_place =[[Islamabad]], [[Pakistan]] | death_place =[[Lal Masjid, Islamabad|Lal Masjid]], [[Islamabad]], [[Pakistan]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2007|7|10|1964|1|29}} |death_cause = Gunshot injury |nationality = [[Pakistan |Pakistani]] |children = Haroon Rashid Ghazi
Haris Rashid Ghazi
Hamza Rashid Ghazi |alma_mater = [[Quaid-i-Azam University]] |module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes battles =[[War in North-West Pakistan]]
[[Siege of Lal Masjid]] † *[[Soviet war in Afghanistan]] }} }} '''Abdul Rashid ''' (عبدالرشيد; ca. 1964 – July 10, 2007)Cameron-Moore, Simon [https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSISL18833720070710 "Pakistan counts costs of bloody end to mosque siege"] Reuters, 10, July 2007 retrieved 27 July 2009. was an [[Islamist]] Pakistani fundamentalist and a human rights activist, son of [[Muhammad Abdullah Ghazi]], and younger brother of [[Abdul Aziz (Pakistani cleric)|Maulana Abdul Aziz Ghazi]]. He was descended from the Sadwani [[clan]] of [[Mazari tribe]] in the town of [[Rojhan]] in [[Rajanpur]], the border district of [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]] province of [[Pakistan]].[http://www.bbc.co.uk/urdu/Pakistan/story/2007/07/070711_rajanpur_ghazi_rs.shtml Tadfeen Islamabad mein ki jaey] BBCUrdu, 11 July 2007, retrieved 21 July 2009 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108223726/http://www.bbc.co.uk/urdu/Pakistan/story/2007/07/070711_rajanpur_ghazi_rs.shtml |date=November 8, 2012 }} Abdul Rashid was killed during [[Operation Silence]] after Pakistan Army Special Operations Commandos' teams stormed the Madrasah he and his students had been using. == Early life == In his youth Abdul Rashid defied his father's wish that he receive formal Islamic education as he wanted to live a modern life. He completed his MSc in International Relations from [[Quaid-e-Azam University]] Islamabad in 1987–1988.[http://www.Pakistantimes.net/2007/07/11/top1.htm "Islamabad Red Mosque Cleric Killed"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070712224737/http://www.pakistantimes.net/2007/07/11/top1.htm |date=2007-07-12 }} Pakistan Times, 11 July 2007, retrieved 27 July 2009 According to one of his professors, "He was a normal, modern student who was well adjusted to a co-educational system." == Work for UN == After taking an M.Sc. in history, he obtained a job at The Ministry of Education in Islamabad, and later worked with [[UNESCO]], a specialized agency of the [[United Nations]] (UN) based in Paris, as Seventeenth Grade Officer. [[File:Maulana Ghazi in 1992 1.jpg|thumb|Maulana Abdul Rasheed Ghazi in his office during his job for [[United Nations]]]] ==Soviet Afghan War== During The [[Soviet–Afghan War|Soviet Invasion Of Afghanistan]] His Father [[Muhammad Abdullah Ghazi]] Played A Major role in Recruiting and Training [[mujahideen]],And In 1998, Abdul Rasheed Ghazi And His Father Maulana Abdullah Ghazi Met [[Osama Bin Laden| Bin Laden]], Ghazi Recalling The Events Once Said Stated : "The Meeting Inspired Me To Work Hard For The Establishment of Islam" He Further Recalled That At The End Of Meeting He Picked Up A Glass From Which Bin Laden Was Drinking Water And Drank It, An amused Bin Laden Asked Ghazi, Why He Did That? To Which Ghazi Replied : I Drank From Your Glass So That Allah Would Make Me A (Great) Warrior Like [[Osama Bin Laden|You]] == Assassination of father == A week after Ghazi and [[Muhammad Abdullah Ghazi|his father]] returned from [[Kandahar]], on Saturday October 17, 1998, Ghazi's father who had a routine every day whereby he would walk to his seminary (the Al Faridia University in Sector E-7 Of [[Islamabad]]) for giving lectures, At noon when he returned [[Abdul Aziz (Pakistani cleric)|his elder son]] approached him and spoke to him. When Maulana approached his house, a man standing in front of the door walked towards him and pulled out a gun and opened fire until the magazine was empty, badly injuring Maulana. Afterwards, he fired at [[Abdul Aziz (Pakistani cleric)|Abdul Aziz Ghazi]], who barely escaped death. The assassin escaped with the help of an accomplice waiting outside in a car. Maulana Abdullah died of his injuries on the way to the hospital. Abdul Rashid Ghazi lodged the FIR and the police investigated the case. After a relentless effort, a man was arrested and afterwards, during [[Police lineup|ID Parade]] Several Eye witnesses identified the assassin. However, he was released the next day without reason. Abdul Rashid Ghazi protested against the release and warned the police of legal action if the suspect was not arrested soon. With Ghazi increasing pressure on police, a military officer asked Ghazi to withdraw the case or face the fate of his father.According to his friend, this was turning point in Ghazi's life, and he became disillusioned him with system. == Post 2001 == Abdul Rashid Ghazi first came to the scene in the year 2001, when the religious parties of the country announced an organization for the defense of Afghanistan against the American invasion. Abdul Rashid Ghazi, who had now been a Maulana, did not suddenly have any religious religious education and degree, was considered the main leader of Mawlawi's alliance. Everyday in Islamabad, there would be a rally and Maulana Abdul Rashid Ghazi addressed in the emotional way standing with other religious leaders. In August 2004, The Pakistan government claimed He Was involved in a plot against the president, the army and parliament; however this was later refuted by the government minister for religious affairs And Later On By The Government.Farooqui, Asif [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/6281228.stm "Obituary: Abdul Rashid "], ''BBC'', July, 2007, retrieved 27 July 2009. ==Activism== Ghazi was a well-known activist against [[Forced disappearance in Pakistan| Enforced disappearances]] in Pakistan, and in 2004 , he founded Defense of Muslim Rights, and Later On in 2006, he Co-founded [https://www.facebook.com/DHRPK/ Defence of Human Rights Pakistan]. Alongside human rights activist [[Amina Masood Janjua]] And [[Khalid Khawaja]] == Assassination attempt == In early 2005, one morning just after dawn, Ghazi was returning from teaching a class at The Al Faridia Seminary (which he managed and was the chancellor of). He was driving along a four-lane highway in the shadow of the [[Margalla Hills]] when he noticed that someone in a nearby car was waving a gun at him. Ghazi fired warning shots from his licensed pistol, confusing the assassins, after which they sped away. ==Death And Legacy== After negotiations Allegedly failed, the military decided to take an action against, and it began as Pakistan Army Special Forces (SF), [[Pakistan Army Rangers]], and [[Special Service Group]] (SSG) stormed the mosque. Ghazi himself remained in seminary with a few students. He called for a safe way in which he would not be humiliated like his brother, but government denied his requests. The [[Ministry of Interior (Pakistan)|Pakistan Ministry of Interior]] reported that he was killed on 10 July 2007 during [[Siege of Lal Masjid|Operation Silence]]. According to the ISPR, the body of was found in the basement of the Lal Masjid. A few days after his death, his famous saying "[http://content.time.com/time/quotes/0,26174,1640613,00.html We can be martyred but we will not surrender]" was featured as Quote of the Day on [[Time (magazine)|Time]]'s website. On July 14, a few days after the Lal Masjid siege, [[Osama bin Laden]] released a tape. He was shown with a fatigued expression. "We in [[al Qaeda]] organization call on God to witness that we will retaliate for the blood of ... Abdul Rashid Ghazi and those with him against Musharraf and those who help him, and for all the pure and innocent blood," he said. On [[September 20, 2007 Osama bin Laden video|September 20, 2007]], Bin Laden released a new tape called "Come to Jihad" with his voice over previously released footage of him. In the tape bin Laden called on Pakistanis to overthrow President Pervez Musharraf, promising what he called retaliation for the storming of the [[Red Mosque]]. == References == * http://content.time.com/time/quotes/0,26174,1640613,00.html == External links == {{Wikiquote}} * {{wikinews-inline|Pakistani army storms Red Mosque; is killed}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20170425084313/http://www.jhuf.net/ Jamia Hafsa Forum] * {{Official website|http://www.jamiah-hafsa.com|Jamia Hafsa official website}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ghazi, Abdul Rashid}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Pakistani Muslims]] [[Category:Deobandis]] [[Category:Pakistani religious leaders]] [[Category:Baloch people]] [[Category:Quaid-i-Azam University alumni]] [[Category:People from Rajanpur District]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{infobox ethnic group| |group=Americans in Pakistan |image= |pop= '''52,486''' (2015)<ref name="Gishkori"/> |popplace=[[Karachi]]{{·}} [[Lahore]]{{·}} [[Islamabad]]{{·}} [[Peshawar]] |rels=[[Protestantism]]{{·}}[[Roman Catholicism]]{{·}}[[Islam]] |langs=[[American English]]{{·}} [[Urdu]]</small>{{·}} [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] |related=[[People of the United States|American]]s }}
'''Americans in Pakistan''' ([[Urdu]]: امریکی ) form a sizeable expatriate community. According to Pakistan's [[Ministry of Interior and Narcotics Control|Ministry of Interior]], there were 52,486 American citizens residing in Pakistan as of 2015.<ref name="Gishkori">{{cite news|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/929229/over-280000-immigrants-living-in-pakistan-says-nisar/|title=Karachi has witnessed 43% decrease in target killing: Nisar|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|date=30 July 2015|accessdate=3 August 2017|first=Zahid|last=Gishkori|quote=As many as 116,308 Afghan nationals are living as immigrants in the country, higher than any other country,” Nisar told the House. Besides Afghans, 52,486 Americans, 79,447 British citizens and 17,320 Canadians are residing in the country, the interior minister added.}}</ref> Some of them are [[Pakistani Americans]] who have returned to Pakistan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2016/11/expatriate-americans-pakistan-donald-trump-win-161101201412656.html|title=Expatriate Americans in Pakistan on Donald Trump's win|work=Al Jazeera|date=13 November 2016|accessdate=13 November 2016|first=Sanam|last=Maher}}</ref> Many Pakistani Americans returned during the unstable conditions post-[[September 11 attacks]] and the [[global financial crisis]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1317845/trumps-executive-order-adding-interest-pakistans-property-market/|title=Trump’s executive order adding to interest in Pakistan’s property market|work=Express Tribune|date=5 February 2017|accessdate=7 February 2017|first=Talha|last=Khan|first2=Farhan|last2=Zaheer}}</ref>
According to early statistics of 1999 based on registrations with the local American embassy and consulates, there were over 4,200 Americans in the country, with 2,100 in Pakistan's financial capital [[Karachi]], about 1,250 in [[Lahore]], 506 in [[Islamabad]] and 375 in [[Peshawar]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.overseasdigest.com/amcit_nu2.htm |title=Private American Citizens Residing Abroad |publisher=Bureau of Consular Affairs |year=1999 |accessdate=2009-09-17 |postscript=<!--none--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326040310/http://www.overseasdigest.com/amcit_nu2.htm |archivedate=26 March 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Employment and social life== {{Citation needed span|text=Most American expatriates in Pakistan tend to be professionals in [[White-collar worker|white collar]] jobs.|date=April 2010}} America also maintains a large diplomatic and military contingent in the country; media reports claim that {{asof|2009|lc=on}}, in addition to 275 diplomats, there are more than a thousand [[United States Marine Corps|US Marines]] providing security to diplomatic personnel, and hundreds more unregistered officials living in private houses. This represents significant growth over 1999, when the American diplomatic contingent in the country barely exceeded one hundred people. However, Pakistani officials deny the reports of more than a thousand US Marines in the country.<ref>{{citation|title=Foreign diplomatic presence: US, UK, Canada increase presence in Pakistan |last=Jamal |first=Akhtar |url=http://pakobserver.net/200909/09/news/topstories04.asp |date=9 September 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-29 |periodical=Pakistan Observer |postscript=<!--none--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913144059/http://pakobserver.net/200909/09/news/topstories04.asp |archivedate=13 September 2009 |df=dmy }} </ref>
For the American community in Karachi, the American Club once was the centre of their social life.<ref name="LATimes">{{citation|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/nov/14/news/mn-53634|periodical=Los Angeles Times|date=14 November 1997|accessdate=2009-09-17|title=After Slayings, Americans in Karachi Weigh Choices|last=Filkins|first=Dexter|postscript=<!--none-->}}</ref> There is also an [[Karachi American School|American School of Karachi]], but {{asof|2013|lc=on}} it had only a handful of American students and teachers.<ref name="NYTimes">{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/19/international/19AMER.html|title=Threats and Responses: Out in the World; Americans Abroad Cope With Anger at U.S.|last=Perlez|first=Jane|date=19 February 2003|accessdate=2009-09-17|periodical=The New York Times}}</ref>
In late 2009, Pakistan held up many visas for U.S. diplomats, military service members and others, because of hostility inside Pakistan toward the expansion of U.S. operations in the country,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://geo.tv/12-17-2009/54916.htm |title=Diplomat: Pakistan holding up some US visas |publisher=GEO News |accessdate=19 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091220042831/http://www.geo.tv/12-17-2009/54916.htm |archivedate=20 December 2009 }}</ref> while many suspected Americans living in Pakistan were detained following five American [[terrorists]] linked to [[Al-Qaeda]] arrested in [[Sargodha]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8436747.stm | work=BBC News | title=US men face court in Pakistan | date=31 December 2009 | accessdate=2010-04-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iGwgTMDR4JE8MmhiWQXVaGGvk2Mw|title=Pakistan court bars deportation of US suspects|publisher=AFP|accessdate=19 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091211/ap_on_re_us/us_pakistan_us_arrests_probe |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213031201/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091211/ap_on_re_us/us_pakistan_us_arrests_probe |archivedate=13 December 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Relations with Pakistani society== {{See also|CIA activities in Pakistan}} In the latter half of 2009, many media organizations reported about the possible presence in Pakistan of personnel from the American private military corporation [[Xe (company)|Xe]] (formerly Blackwater).{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} Several American suspects were arrested in Pakistan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Another US national arrested in Pakistan|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/150650.html|accessdate=14 November 2010|newspaper=PressTV|date=12 Nov 2010 }}</ref> The presence of these American personnel has been a controversial issue in Pakistani media and has caused uproar in the general public, with people questioning their activities in the country and viewing them as spies.
Pakistani newspapers claim that American diplomats in Pakistan carried automatic weapons without a license, attacked local citizens, and cursed at local policemen.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Politics/05-Sep-2009/A-law-unto-themselves/|periodical=The Nation|date=5 September 2009|accessdate=2009-09-20|title=A law unto themselves|first=Sikander|last=Shaheen|postscript=<!--none-->}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2009/07/05/77897.html|date=5 July 2009|accessdate=2009-09-29|periodical=Al-Arabiya News Channel|title=Americans carry arms in defiance of diplomatic law: US diplomats in Islamabad carry arms for safety|last=Jafar|first=Mansoor|postscript=<!--none-->}}</ref> They have also allegedly dodged law enforcement personnel and security screenings on motorways,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/236756/us-men-dodge-motorway-police-to-enter-peshawar/|title=US men dodge Motorway police to enter Peshawar|date=22 August 2011|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> airports and elsewhere on multiple occasions. In January 2011, an American national and CIA contractor [[Raymond Allen Davis incident|Raymond Davis]] was involved in a shootout that killed three Pakistanis in [[Lahore]], resulting in a diplomatic rift between Pakistan and the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/27/us-embassy-official-kills-pakistan | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Declan | last=Walsh | title=US foreign policy,World news,US news,Pakistan (News) | date=27 January 2011}}</ref> Davis was later freed by the Pakistani government and the families of the victims were paid compensation, in spite of large public opposition to his acquittal. In February 2011, American citizen Aaron Mark DeHaven was arrested in Peshawar after he was found allegedly overstaying his visa illegally. He was later deported. In May 2011, an American national Mathew Greg Bennett was tailed and arrested by law enforcement agencies in [[Rawalpindi]] on claims of involvement in suspicious activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/168672/american-citizen-arrested-in-rawalpindi/|title=American citizen arrested in Rawalpindi|date=14 May 2011|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> In June 2011, an American citizen living in Pakistan with his Pakistani wife and family, Mathew Craig Barret, was arrested in Islamabad. Barret was suspected to be spying on the country's nuclear facilities and was blacklisted by the interior ministry after he had dodged an earlier arrest allegedly after being found doing "suspicious activities." Following a police raid in his house, he was put in lock-up jail<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/world/american-arrested-in-pakistan-for-overstaying_711976.html|title=American arrested in Pakistan for overstaying|work=Zee News|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> and was to be deported and prevented from entering the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/186995/american-citizen-on-14-day-judicial-remand-faces-deportation/|title=Serious allegations: Detained US citizen faces deportation in a few days|date=12 June 2011|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> On 12 June 2011, yet another American national was arrested, this time in [[Sukkur]]; David Sat, who was working for an NGO, was detained by authorities after he was found to have overstayed his visa by two months. A case was registered against him.<ref>[http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online//Politics/12-Jun-2011/Another-American-held Another American held]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/06/sukkur-police-arrests-another-illegal-american/|title=Sukkur police arrests another illegal American|publisher=|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> Pakistani security and defence expert [[Shireen Mazari]], who is also known for being a vocal critic of American policies, once had a verbal brawl in an Islamabad restaurant with an American man whom she later referred to as a "bloody CIA agent"; Mazari said that suspicious looking Americans are prevalent in large numbers in Islamabad, operating under the cover of diplomacy, and that they are "running loose in Islamabad intimidating whomever they choose."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahmedquraishi.com/2011/06/14/%E2%80%98fuck-you-lady%E2%80%99-a-us-embassy-man-yells-at-dr-shireen-mazari-in-islamabad-restaurant/|title=Account Suspended|publisher=|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
Pakistan has blacklisted many American non-governmental organizations and media personalities and denied visas to US nationals.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009%5C09%5C13%5Cstory_13-9-2009_pg1_5 |periodical=Pakistan Daily Times |date=13 September 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-29 |title=Harassing Americans will hurt Pakistan: Haqqani |postscript=<!--none--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922173917/http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009%5C09%5C13%5Cstory_13-9-2009_pg1_5 |archivedate=22 September 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{citation|date=13 September 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-29 |url=http://www.geo.tv/9-13-2009/49123.htm |title=Visa denial to US citizens earns Pak bad name: Haqqani |periodical=Geo Television Network |postscript=<!--none--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915183718/http://geo.tv/9-13-2009/49123.htm |archivedate=15 September 2009 }}</ref>
In 2011, after continuous scrutiny and following the [[death of Osama bin Laden]] in his [[Osama bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad|compound in Abbottabad]] which caused a diplomatic controversy between Pakistan and the United States, the Pakistani government and the military establishment ordered the reduction of the number of American personnel present in Pakistan. Consequently, many American security personnel were dumped and forced to leave the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/186242/us-military-presence-reduced-in-pakistan-embassy/|title=US military presence reduced in Pakistan: Embassy|date=10 June 2011|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
In 2003, the American actor [[Erik Audé]] was arrested and imprisoned for seven years in Pakistan on charges of drug trafficking.
In 1997, four American oil workers and their driver were shot by multiple gunmen while they sat in their car on a crowded street.<ref name="LATimes"/> Two men, both members of the [[Muttahida Qaumi Movement]], were sentenced to death in 1999 for the shootings.<ref>{{citation|periodical=The New York Times|title=2 to Die for Killing Americans in Pakistan|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/22/world/2-to-die-for-killing-americans-in-pakistan.html|date=22 August 1999|accessdate=2009-09-17|postscript=<!--none-->}}</ref> In 2002, there were further terrorist attacks against Americans and expatriates of other nationalities, including [[Karachi consulate attacks|a bombing at the US consulate]]. In November 2008, foreign aid worker Stephen Vance was ambushed and killed on his way to work in Peshawar.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/13/world/asia/13pstan.html|title=U.S. Aid Worker Slain in Pakistan|last=Perlez|first=Jane|date=12 November 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> In 2003, ''[[The New York Times]]'' named Karachi "one of the most dangerous spots on the planet for an American".<ref name="NYTimes"/> In 2015, an American medical professor was shot and injured in Karachi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/870894/us-national-injured-after-being-shot-twice-in-the-head-in-karachi/|title=Islamic State leaflets found at shooting site of 'US national' in Karachi|date=16 April 2015|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref>
==Education== American international schools in Pakistan include: * [[International School of Islamabad]]<!--http://www.isoi.edu.pk/uploaded/documents/About_ISOI/School_History_v6_-_100826.pdf--> * [[Karachi American School]] * [[Lahore American School]]
==Notable people== {{See|List of Americans in Pakistan}}
==See also== {{Portal|United States|Pakistan}} *[[Anti-American sentiment in Pakistan]] *[[2010 CIA Station Chief removal in Pakistan]] *[[Pakistani American]] * [[Canadians in Pakistan]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *{{Citation|last=Lindenbaum|first=John|title=Small intestine dysfunction in Pakistanis and Americans resident in Pakistan|pmid=5675841|journal=Am J Clin Nutr|volume=21|pages=1023–9|year=1968|issue=9|postscript=<!--none-->}} *{{Citation|title=American professors in West Pakistan: a study of cross-cultural relations|last=Winter|first=David Kenneth|series=Ph.D. dissertation|year=1968|oclc=25861407|publisher=Michigan State University|postscript=<!--none-->}} * [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-south-asia-14790457 American diplomats in Pakistan under pressure] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150629171652/http://islamabad.usembassy.gov/pr-10051001.html Correction For The Record: U.S. Embassy Construction Nears Completion]

'''Business interaction networks''' are networks that allow businesses and their communities of interest to collaborate and do business online securely via the [[Internet]].<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jRIEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA34&lpg=PA34&dq=%22business+interaction+networks%22+network+world&source=bl&ots=J0ra0NYjmu&sig=Ve9afBpbCgRXrv1oUHklIAlHOkw&hl=en&ei=gq1sS6bhEJTwsQPswoyyDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CBAQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22business%20interaction%20networks%22%20network%20world&f=false | title=Deal underscores need for users to get serious about Internet services | author=Turner, Mary Johnston | publisher = [[Network World]] | accessdate = February 5, 2010}}</ref>
Mary Johnston Turner first discussed the concept in a [[Network World]] opinion piece in August, 1995, and attributed the first advocacy for the concept to the now-defunct [[BBN_Planet#Computer_technologies_since_the_1990s|BBN Planet]], the ISP division of [[BBN Technologies]].

{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Chinese people in Angola |population=50,000 (2017)<ref name="angoladown">{{cite news|title=Chinese Businesses Quit Angola After `Disastrous' Currency Blow|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-20/chinese-businesses-quit-angola-after-disastrous-currency-blow|publisher=Bloomberg|date=April 20, 2017}}</ref> |popplace=[[Luanda]] |related-c=[[Overseas Chinese]], [[Macanese people]] }} '''Chinese people in Angola''' are a recent group of residents, having arrived in [[Angola]] in the past few decades.
Thousands of Chinese construction workers, engineers, planners, and support staff that includes doctors and cooks reside in Angola, making the construction sector a large magnet for Chinese.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7047127.stm | work=BBC News | first=Lucy | last=Ash | title=Chinese reaching out to Angola | date=4 December 2007}}</ref>
Over 500 Chinese companies have operated in Angola, as part of post-war reconstruction.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chinese firms urged to beef up security in Angola amid worrying crimes - Xinhua {{!}} English.news.cn|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-05/12/c_135354554.htm|accessdate=27 August 2016|work=news.xinhuanet.com}}</ref> The height of the wave was around 2012 when Angola's Office of Migration and Foreigners, stated 258,920 Chinese resided in Angola, the vast majority (258,391) on work visas.<ref name="Visao">{{citation|url=https://visao.sapo.pt/angola-cerca-de-259000-chineses-vivem-atualmente-no-pais=f660830|title=Angola: Cerca de 259.000 chineses vivem atualmente no país|work=Visão|date=2012-04-25|accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
The level of the Chinese population before the crash in oil prices in 2014 has fallen dramatically. In 2017, a Chinese business association leader told Bloomberg that the population was approximately 50,000.<ref name="angoladown"/> Many Chinese have left the country recently because of rising crime against Chinese, including rapes, robberies and murder, the depreciation of Angola currency due to the oil crash, and halting of construction contracts by Chinese companies.<ref>{{cite news|title=INTERVIEW-Rise in violent crime alarms Chinese in Angola{{!}} News by Country{{!}} Reuters|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/angolaNews/idAFLB37077620091111|accessdate=27 August 2016|work=af.reuters.com}}</ref><ref name="angoladown"/>
During [[2016 Angola and DR Congo yellow fever outbreak|a large outbreak of yellow fever in Angola]] in the spring of 2016, eleven Chinese nationals were reported to have traveled home to China with the disease, with the last case in April 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow Fever – China|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/22-april-2016-yellow-fever-china/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=1 May 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref> The Chinese strengthened surveillance and sent a medical team to Angola to provide vaccination to Chinese nationals.

{{about|the demographics|information about other facets of Białystok|Białystok}} {{Historical populations |source = <ref name="stat.gov.pl">Central Statistical Office, Warsaw 2009, {{cite web |url=http://www.stat.gov.pl/gus/yearbooks_ENG_HTML.htm |title=Statistical Yearbooks of Poland |accessdate=2011-01-12 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101210081738/http://www.stat.gov.pl/gus/yearbooks_ENG_HTML.htm |archivedate=2010-12-10 |df= }}</ref> |1857|13787 |1889|56629 |1901|65781 |1939|107000 |1946|56759 |1950|68503 |1955|97192 |1960|120921 |1965|139986 |1970|168500 |1975|195861 |1980|224187 |1990|270568 |2000|285507 |2006|294830 |2011|295198 |2015|295981 |2017|297288 }} Historically, Białystok has been a destination for internal and foreign immigration, especially from [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]]. In addition to the [[Poles|Polish minority]], there was a significant Jewish majority in Białystok. According to [[Russian Empire Census|Russian census of 1897]], out of the total population of 66,000, [[Jews]] constituted 41,900 (around 63% percent).<ref>Joshua D. Zimmerman, ''Poles, Jews and the politics of nationality'', Univ of Wisconsin Press, 2004, {{ISBN|0-299-19464-7}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=6sbr9cZyw_4C&pg=PA16&dq=population+Brest+Poles+Jews&lr=&as_brr=3&ei=HS_3SZ2-NITyzQSUtaWtBQ Google Print, p. 16]</ref> World War II changed all of this, in 1939, ca. 107,000 persons lived in Białystok,<ref>{{en icon}} {{cite book | author = Dānishgāh-i Tihrān. Faculty of Fine Arts| coauthors = | title = International Conference on Reconstruction of War-Damaged Areas: 6–16 March 1986 : Faculty of Fine Arts, University of Tehran, Iran| year = 1990 | editor = | page =148 | pages = | chapter = | chapterurl = | publisher =University of Tehran Press| location = | isbn =| url = | format = | accessdate = }}</ref> but in 1946 – only 56,759, and to this day there is much less ethnic diversity than in the previous 300 years of the city's history.<ref name="ushmm">{{en icon}} {{cite web |author= |url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/article.php?lang=en&ModuleId=10005069 |title=Białystok |work=www.ushmm.org |publisher= |pages= |page= |date= |accessdate=29 August 2008}}</ref> Currently the city's population is 97% Polish, 2.5% Belarusian and 0.5% of a number of minorities including Russians, Lipka Tartars, Ukrainians and Romani.<ref name="stat.gov.pl"/> Most of the modern day population growth is based on internal migration and urbanization.
The largest population in Białystok occurred in 2017 as reported by [[Główny Urząd Statystyczny|GUS]] 297 288 people. ==National minorities== {{further|Ethnic minorities in Poland}}
===Belarusians=== {{further|Belarusian minority in Poland}} Białystok is a center of culture and society of Belarus (according to the census, they are almost 7,500, which represents 2.5% of residents of Białystok).<ref name="MSWIA">[http://www.mswia.gov.pl/portal/pl/61/37/ Mniejszości narodowe i etniczne w Polsce] {{pl icon}}</ref> There is a Belarus Consulate in the city, and organizations exist such as the Belarusian Social and Cultural Association,<ref>[http://bazy.ngo.pl/search/info.asp?id=922&p=daneInne Białoruskie Towarzystwo Społeczno-Kulturalne w ngo.pl], bazy.ngo.pl, [data aktualizacji bazy: 2009-09-01 ]</ref> the Belarusian Youth Union, the Union of Belarus to Poland, the Belarusian Association of Literary Bialowieza, Belarusian Historical Society,<ref>[http://www.kamunikat.org/]</ref> Belarusian Association of Journalists, Belarusian Students Association,<ref>Sławomir Iwaniuk, ''[http://www.slonko.com.pl/czasopis/in.php?id=0605/2006_05_c14 25-lecie Białoruskiego Zrzeszenia Studentów]'', "Беларускі грамадска-культурны часопіс" (pol. "Czasopis. Białoruskie pismo społeczno-kulturalne") 05/2006 [Dostęp 07.01.2011)</ref> Center for Civic Education, Poland-Belarus, Society of Belarusian Culture.
Bialystok also hosts cultural events such as nationwide Festival "Belarusian Song" and Day of Belarusian Culture.<ref>[http://www.bialystok.pl/]</ref> Belarus Radio Right ({{lang|pl|Białoruskie Radio Racja}})<ref name=koncesje>{{cite web|url=http://www.krrit.gov.pl/bip/Nadawcy/Nadawcykoncesjonowani/Koncesjeradiowe/tabid/216/Default.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20080729021246/http://www.krrit.gov.pl/bip/Nadawcy/Nadawcykoncesjonowani/Koncesjeradiowe/tabid/216/Default.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-07-29 |title=Koncesje na rozpowszechnianie programów radiowych drogą naziemną |publisher=[[Krajowa Rada Radiofonii i Telewizji|KRRiTv]] |language=pl |date=2010-04-12 }}</ref> is based in the city and transmits radio programming to Belarus. There are a number of Belarusian-language newspapers: Niwa,<ref>[http://niva.iig.pl/]</ref> Belarusian Historical Papers,<ref>[http://katalog.czasopism.pl/index.php/Bia%C5%82oruskie_Zeszyty_Historyczne ''Białoruskie Zeszyty Historyczne'']</ref> Pravincyja and Czasopis.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://kamunikat.org/czasopis/| title = Wybrane artykuły z miesięcznika w wersji elektronicznej| date = 11 June 2009| author = | publisher = Беларуская Iнтзрнзт-Бiблiятзка "Камунiкат" (Białoruska Biblioteka Internetowa "Komunikat")| data = | language = be, pl, en}}</ref>
===Russians=== [[Russians]] are a minority, they are scattered around the territory of Poland but mostly reside in eastern Poland. There are 3244 Russians in Poland, living mainly in Białystok and the surrounding region, according to the 2002 census.<ref name="MSWIA"/> The HFHR estimated around 13,000-15,000 [[Russians]] are in Poland. In Białystok, the main organization of work - Russian Cultural and Educational Association, organizing the Days of Russian Culture.
===Tatars=== {{further|Lipka Tatars}} The Lipka Tatar origins can be traced back to the descendant states of the [[Mongol Empire]] of [[Genghis Khan]] - the [[White Horde]], the [[Golden Horde]], the [[Crimean Khanate]] and [[Kazan Khanate]]. They initially served as a noble military caste but later they became urban-dwellers known for their crafts, horses and gardening skills. Throughout centuries they resisted assimilation and kept their traditional lifestyle. While they remained very attached to their religions, over time however, they lost their original [[Tatar language]] and for the most part adopted [[Polish language|Polish]].<ref name="Harvard">Harvard Encyclopedia of American Ethnic Groups, "Polish or Lithuanian Tartars", Harvard University Press, pg. 990</ref>
After the annexation of eastern Poland into the Soviet Union following World War II, Poland was left with only 2 Tatar villages, [[Bohoniki]] and [[Kruszyniany]]. A significant number of the Tartars in the territories annexed to the USSR repatriated to Poland and clustered in or near Białystok. In Poland, the Tatar population reached approximately 100,000 in 1630 but the 2002 census showed only 447 people declaring this ethnicity.<ref name="MSWIA"/>
In 1925 the Muslim Religion Association (Muzułmański Związek Religijny) was formed in Białystok. In 1992, the ''Organization of Tatars of the Polish Republic'' (Związek Tatarów Rzeczypospolitej Polskiej) with autonomous branches in Białystok and Gdańsk began operating. The Białystok branch issues a magazine called ''Life Tatar''. The plan is to establish in Bialystok an '''Institute for the History of the Tartars''.
===Other nationalities===
In Bialystok there are other minorities: * '''[[Romani people|Romani]]''' - Emigration of Polish Romani to Germany in the late 1980s reduced Poland's Romani population by as much as 75 percent. In Białystok the ''Central Council of Roma'' work in Poland, and publish a monthly magazine, ''Rromano po Drom'' * '''[[Ukrainians in Poland|Ukrainians]]''' - According to the census 417 Ukrainians live in Białystok,<ref name="MSWIA"/> There are two civic societies in the city, ''the Association of Ukrainians of Podlasie'' and ''Association of Independent Ukrainian Youth''.

{{Refimprove|date=May 2009}}
Sardar Meer '''Dil Murad Khan Khoso''' was a [[Baloch people|Baloch]] warrior who opposed British invasion in his area by revolting against them in 1857.<ref>{{cite book |title=Biographical encyclopedia of Pakistan |last= |first= |year=1972 |publisher=Biographical Research Institute, Pakistan |isbn= |page=528 }}</ref> Being a [[sardar]] of the [[Khoso]] tribe<ref name=bep2000>{{cite book |title=Biographical encyclopedia of Pakistan: millennium 2000 |last= |first= |year=2001 |publisher=Research Institute of Historiography, Biography and Philosophy |oclc=50495187 |page=645 }}</ref> he had a good support of his tribesmen plus that of other sardars of the area, namely Sardar Dariya Khan Jakhrani<ref name=Lambrick/> and Syed Inayat Ali Shah.
On the evening before they were to fight with British troops someone leaked information about the whereabouts of the warriors and their plan.<ref name=Lambrick>{{cite book |title=John Jacob of Jacobabad |last=Lambrick |first=Hugh Trevor |year=1960 |publisher=[[Orion Publishing Group|Cassell]] |oclc=314950185 |page=333 }}</ref> Who leaked this information to British is not known. All the three sardars were arrested taken to some unknown area and then Dil Murad Khan was sentenced to life imprisonment,<ref>{{cite book |title=Inside Baluchistan: a political autobiography of His Highness Baiglar Baigi, Khan-e-Azam-XIII Mir Ahmad Yar Khan Baluch, Khan-e-Baluch, ex-ruler of Kalat State |last=K̲h̲ān |first=Aḥmad Yār |year=1975 |publisher=Royal Book Co. |oclc=2789395 |page=188 }}</ref> in the [[Andaman Islands]]<ref name=bep2000/> while his campanions were sent to [[Aden]].
After his arrest his brother Shahal Khan I was imprisoned at Mach jail and was made to crush glasses that affected his eyesight and became blind and later on released as a blind person.
When all this happened Dil Murad khan and Darya Khan Jakhrani had a vast area of agricultural land under their possession. All the land was confiscated and the Sardar title was taken back. Bahadur Khan [[Mir Bahadur Khan Khoso]], the only son of Dil Murad Khan was a small boy and his mother Seza, a [[Jamali (tribe)|Jamali]] woman by tribe, took her son to General [[John Jacob (East India Company officer)|John Jacob]]'s [[Durbar (court)|Durbar]] and bravely spoke to him saying, "I am just a woman with a blind brother in law. I cannot support this boy so I request you to kindly arrest my son and send him to his father". John Jacob was quite moved by these bold remarks of a tribal woman and ordered a piece of land to be given to the family near [[Dilmurad Wah]] in [[Thul]] Taluka.
[[Mir Bahadur Khan Khoso]] pursued a different life style and he proved himself to be an inventive genius who advised engineers on various irrigation projects. Bahadur Khan had more than forty thousand acres of land in [[Jacobabad District]] all purchased by himself.

{{Infobox artist | image = Dolk - Spray.JPG | caption = Dolks "Spray" | name = Dolk (Dolk Lundgren) | birth_name = Unknown | birth_date = 1979 | birth_place = [[Bergen]], Norway | nationality = [[Norwegians|Norwegian]] | field = [[Stencil graffiti]]
[[Street art]] | movement = [[Social commentary]] | website = {{URL|http://www.dolk.no}} }} '''Dolk''' (meaning ''dagger'' in [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]) ('''Dolk Lundgren'''),{{cite web|url=http://www.studvest.no/kultur.php?art_id=2441/|work=Subject street art|title=Vandal artists|date=21 May 2008|first=Ruth Hege|last=Halstensen|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Studvest.no|language=Norwegian}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} is the pseudonym of Norway's most recognized [[Stencil Graffiti|stencil artist]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ba.no/puls/article5037839.ece|work=Newspaper|title=Norway's street art capital|date=24 March 2010|first= Ann Kristin|last= Ødegård|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Ba.no|language=Norwegian}} His motives are often pop-cultural references put into a humoristic or critical context. Dolk's works can be seen on walls in cities such as [[Bergen]], [[Berlin]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Barcelona]], [[Oslo]], [[Lisbon]], [[Stockholm]], [[London]], [[Prague]] and [[Melbourne]]. Since 2006 Dolk has stepped into galleries where he has had several exhibitions.{{cite web|url=http://www.ba.no/puls/article5726885.ece|work=Newspaper art|title=Why Dolk did not choose Bergen|date=18 September 2011|first= Ørjan|last= Nilsson|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Ba.no|language=Norwegian}} == Biography == ===Career=== [[File:Dolk - 3 (writer).jpg|thumb|left|Dolk - Puppy Love, [[Bergen]], Norway]] Dolk was born in Bergen, Norway, in 1979 and started with [[stencil art]] in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://graffiti.no/streetart/index.htm|work=Subject: Street Art|title=Dolk and Pøbel|date=10 June 2014|first= Thomas|last= Stønjum |accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Graffiti.no|language=Norwegian}} Dolk has education from mechanic courses in Bergen, and has studied graphic design in Melbourne. Dolk claims he was inspired by the British street artist [[Banksy]] to start with stencil art. Dolk started with stencil art in Bergen in 2003, where several of his works still are visible on walls in the city. He soon started travelling the world, and in London people have mistaken Dolk's works for being art by Banksy.{{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/kultur-og-underholdning/1.3269330|work= Newspaper|title=Dolk does it sharp in London|date=23 August 2007|first= Marthe|last= Solbakken|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=NRK.no|language=Norwegian}} Dolk has made stencil art in many cities. After a while Dolk wanted to take his art into more legal forms and he has since 2006 participated in exhibitions and art festivals all over the world. In 2008 Dolk and [[Pøbel]] created the project "Ghetto Spedalsk" in [[Lofoten]], northern Norway. The goal was to move the urban art form into no man's land by painting 20 stencils on abandoned houses.{{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/nordland/1.6186843|work= Newspaper|title=Urban art in no man's land|date=21 September 2008|first= John Inge|last= Johansen|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=NRK.no|language=Norwegian}} In 2010 Dolk made three works of art for the opening of [[Halden prison]], the art covers the walls in the exercise yard. [[Daily Mail]] called the prison "the world's poshest prison, with plus £1m Banksy-style art".{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1277158/Halden-Prison-Inside-Norways-posh-new-jail.html#ixzz1q8u72jpx|work= Newspaper|title=the world's poshest prison (plus £1m Banksy-style art)|date=12 May 2010|first= |last= |accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Dailymail.co.uk}} In 2010 Dolk and Pøbel were paid by the Norwegian state to put their art up at the main railway stations in [[Oslo]] and [[Trondheim]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/distrikt/nrk_trondelag/1.7101702|work= Newspaper|title=Dolk and Pøbel at the station|date=24 April 2010|first= Torill|last= Aamodt |accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=NRK.no|language=Norwegian}} In 2011 Dolk held his first separate exhibition in Oslo at the OSL Contemporary gallery where he sold out all 9 canvases for £12500 each. In 2011 Dolk was one of several street artists that got to decorate the walls at the [[Norwegian School of Economics]] as part of the project "…………CAPITALISM?".{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.no/bergenpuls/Dolk-pryder-NHH-2566800.html#.T1OHjfEaND1|work=Newspaper art|title=Dolk decorates NHH|date=18 September 2011|first= Kjetil|last= Kopren Ullebø|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Bt.no|language=Norwegian}} Dolk sells his works through the Bergen-based website handmadeposters.com, and in 2011, 250 copies of the print "Mushroom Girl" were sold out in 40 minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.no/bergenpuls/Popular-Dolk-selger-sa-det-suser-2579379.html#.T1OGAfEaND1|work=Newspaper art|title=Dolk sells out fast|date=21 September 2011|first= Guro H.|last= Bergesen|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Bt.no|language=Norwegian}} In 2012 he sold the prints "TOY" and "Winner" for over £110000 in less than two minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.ba.no/puls/article5961065.ece|work=Newspaper art|title=Dolk sells for £110000|date=7 March 2012|first= Ørjan|last= Nilsson|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Ba.no|language=Norwegian}} In 2012, Dolkblog.com was established; the unofficial fansite covers news, artwork, information etc. about the artist.{{cite web|url=http://www.DolkBlog.com|work=Blogart|title=Dolkblog.com|date=31 August 2012|first= |last= |accessdate=31 August 2012|publisher=Dolkblog.com}} ===Exhibitions and festivals=== {{column}} *2004, "Dolk vs. Strøk", Tilsammans, Bergen, Norway. *2005, "Unge(s) spor", USF Verftet, Bergen, Norway. *2006, "Santa`s Ghetto", 15 Oxford Street, London, England. *2006, "Nuart Festival", [[Stavanger]], Norway. *2007, "Difusor", Barcelona, Spain. *2007, "Nuart Festival", Stavanger, Norway. *2008, "The Cans Festival", London, England. *2008, "Urban Affairs: Streetart and Urban Art Exhibition", Berlin, Germany. *2008, "Nuart Festival", Stavanger, Norway. *2008, "Graffle 2", [[Bristol]], England. *2008, "Saints & Sinners", [[Soho]], England. *2008, "Ghetto Spedalsk", Lofoten, Norway. *2009, "Fame Festival", [[Grottaglie]], Italy. *2010, "BGO1", Bergen, Norway. *2010, "Nuart Festival", Stavanger, Norway. *2010, "Brooklynite Gallery", [[New York City]], United States. *2011, "OSL Contemporary", Oslo, Norway. *2012, "…………CAPITALISM?", [[Norwegian School of Economics]], Bergen, Norway. ==Art== ===Dolk or Banksy?=== Early in Dolk's career, it was speculated that Dolk was a pseudonym for the well-known British graffiti artist Banksy. The two artists have several stylistic similarities, and especially Banksy's work "Puppy Love" from 2005 has been pointed out as resembling Dolk. Dolk made his own version of this work where both the name and the colors were identical with the original. ===Famous works=== The work "Che" from 2007 shows a cigar-smoking [[Che Guevara]] proudly pointing at his own t-shirt with the iconic portrait from 1960 taken by [[Alberto Korda]] of himself. Dolk's stencil is distinguished by many as the ultimate copy of this portrait, that after Che Guevara's death was pirate-copied, creating an enormous turnover. The stencil has been sold as the prints "Che" and "Che XL". The well-known street art website "Pictures on Walls" sold Dolk's "Che" as postcards in 2006. The work "Burger King" from 2006 portrays [[Prince Charles]] in a birthday crown in paper from [[Burger King]]. The work "Spray" is a twist on the iconic picture taken by [[Eddie Adams (photographer)|Eddie Adams]] during the [[Vietnam War]] where general [[Nguyễn Ngọc Loan]] executes the [[Vietcong]] prisoner of war [[Nguyễn Văn Lém]] with a head shot. Dolk has exchanged the head with a flower, and the revolver with a spray bottle. In Bergen, this work was preserved in 2009 by the local government framing it in protective glass.{{cite web|url=http://www.ba.no/nyheter/politikk/article4425460.ece|work= Newspaper|title=Defends Dolk preservation |date=26 June 2009|first= Geir |last= Kvile|accessdate=25 March 2012|publisher=Ba.no|language=Norwegian}} The project "Ghetto Spedalsk" in 2008 was a collaboration between Dolk and Pøbel where the goal was to move street art into no man's land. They painted several stencils on 20 abandoned houses in Lofoten, northern Norway. The project got wide international attention.
File:Che and Fidel Graffiti Bergen Norway.JPG|"Che", [Bergen File:Dolk - Spray.JPG|"Spray", Bergen
==See also== {{Commons category|Dolk}} * [[List of street artists]] * [[List of stencil artists]] * [[Glossary of graffiti]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.handmadeposters.com: Handmadeposters - Prints by Dolk] * [http://www.dolk.no: Dolk.no - Official website] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Public art]] [[Category:Pseudonymous artists]] [[Category:Guerilla artists]] [[Category:1979 births]]

revision.text:
[[File:Amulettes phalliques gallo-romaines Musée Saint-Remi 120208.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Gallo-Roman]] examples of the ''fascinum'' in bronze. The topmost is an example of the "fist and phallus" amulet with a ''manus fica''.]] [[File:Pompeji Penis Sign.jpg|thumb|150px|Phallus inscribed on a paving stone at [[Pompeii]]]]
In [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]] and [[Magic in the Graeco-Roman world|magic]], the '''''fascinus''''' or '''''fascinum''''' was the embodiment of the divine [[phallus]]. The word can refer to the deity himself ('''Fascinus'''), to phallus [[effigy|effigies]] and [[amulet]]s, and to the spells used to invoke his divine protection.<ref>The [[grammatical gender|neuter]] form ''fascinum'' is used most often for objects or magic charms, masculine ''fascinus'' for the god.</ref> [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] calls it a ''medicus invidiae'', a "doctor" or remedy for envy (''[[invidia]]'', a "looking upon") or the [[evil eye]].
==Etymology== The English word "[[wikt:fascinate|fascinate]]" ultimately derives from Latin ''[[wikt:fascinum|fascinum]]'' and the related verb ''fascinare'', "to use the power of the ''fascinus''", that is, "to practice magic" and hence "to enchant, bewitch" [[Catullus]] uses the verb at the end of ''Carmen 7'', a [[hendecasyllable|hendecasyllabic]] poem addressing his lover Lesbia; he expresses his infinite desire for kisses that cannot be counted by voyeurs nor "fascinated" (put under a spell) by a malicious tongue; such bliss, as also in ''Carmen'' 5, potentially attracts ''invidia''.<ref>David Wray, [https://books.google.com/books?id=6Qg3kYF-WS4C&pg=PA152&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=14#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false ''Catullus and the Poetics of Roman Manhood''] (Cambridge University Press, 2001), p. 152.</ref>
[[Fescennine Verses]], the satiric and often lewd songs or chants performed on various social occasions, may have been so-named from the ''fascinum''; ancient sources propose this etymology along with an alternative origin from [[Fescennia]], a small town in [[Etruria]].<ref>Gian Biagio Conte, [https://books.google.com/books?id=NJGp_dkXnuUC&pg=PA23&dq=fascinum&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=172#v=onepage&q=fascinum&f=false ''Latin Literature: A History''] (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1987, 1994), p. 23.</ref>
==Public religion== [[File:Tintinnabulum Pompeii MAN Napoli Inv27839.jpg|thumb|upright|150px|Fascinus from Pompeii showing a phallus]] The [[Vestal Virgin]]s tended the cult of the ''fascinus [[SPQR|populi Romani]]'', the sacred image of the phallus that was one of the tokens of the safety of the state ''(sacra Romana)''. It was thus associated with the [[Palladium (classical antiquity)|Palladium]].<ref>R. Joy Littlewood, ''A [[Commentary (philology)|Commentary]] on [[Ovid]]:'' Fasti ''Book 6'' (Oxford University Press, 2006), p. 73; [[T.P. Wiseman]], ''Remus: A Roman Myth'' (Cambridge University Press, 1995), p. 61 [https://books.google.com/books?id=7LPNHRUlWacC&pg=PA61&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=68#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false online.]</ref> [[Roman mythology|Roman myths]], such as the begetting of [[Servius Tullius]], suggest that this phallus was an embodiment of a masculine generative power located within the hearth, regarded as sacred.<ref>Joseph Rykwert, ''The Idea of a Town: The Anthropology of Urban Form in Rome, Italy, and the Ancient World'' (MIT Press, 1988), pp. 101 and 159 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Jq78Ff2TYHAC&pg=PA159&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=2#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false online.]</ref> When a general celebrated a [[Roman triumph|triumph]], the Vestals hung an effigy of the ''fascinus'' on the underside of his [[chariot]] to protect him from ''invidia''.<ref>[[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]], ''Natural History'' 28.4.7 (28.39).</ref>
[[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]], whose primary source on Roman religion was the lost theological works of [[Marcus Terentius Varro]], notes that a phallic image was carried in procession annually at the festival of [[Liber|Father Liber]], the Roman god [[interpretatio graeca|identified with]] [[Dionysus|Dionysus or Bacchus]], for the purpose of protecting the fields from ''fascinatio'', magic compulsion:<ref>[[Augustine of Hippo]], ''[[City of God (book)|De civitate Dei]]'' 7.21; Williams, ''Roman Homosexuality'', p. 92.</ref> {{quote|Varro says that certain rites of Liber were celebrated in Italy which were of such unrestrained wickedness that the shameful parts of the male were worshipped at crossroads in his honour. … For, during the days of the [[Liberalia|festival of Liber]], this obscene member, placed on a little trolley, was first exhibited with great honour at the crossroads in the countryside, and then conveyed into the city itself. … In this way, it seems, the god Liber was to be propitiated, in order to secure the growth of seeds and to repel enchantment ''(fascinatio)'' from the fields.<ref>English translation by R.W. Dyson, ''Augustine: The City of God against the Pagans'' (Cambridge University Press, 1998, 2002), p. 292 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ReU2M8cLtGcC&pg=PA292&dq=%2221+Of+the+wickedness+of+the+rites+celebrated+in+honour+of+Liber%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%2221%20Of%20the%20wickedness%20of%20the%20rites%20celebrated%20in%20honour%20of%20Liber%22&f=false online.]</ref>}} As a divinized phallus, Fascinus shared attributes with [[Mutunus Tutunus]], whose shrine was supposed to date from the [[Founding of Rome|founding of the city]], and the imported Greek god [[Priapus]].<ref>[[Arnobius]], ''Adversus nationes'' 4.7, explicitly connects Tutunus to the ''fascinus''; see [[Robert E.A. Palmer]], "Mutinus Titinus: A Study in Etrusco-Roman Religion and Topography," in ''Roman Religion and Roman Empire: Five Essays'' (University of Pennsylvania Press, 1974), pp. 187–206.</ref>
==As a magic symbol== Phallic charms, often winged, were ubiquitous in Roman culture, appearing as objects of jewellery such as pendants and finger rings, relief carvings, lamps, and wind chimes (''[[Tintinnabulum|tintinnabula]]'').<ref name='CAW'>{{cite book |author1=Williams, C. A. |date=1999 |title=Roman Homosexuality: Ideologies of Masculinity in Classical Antiquity |publisher=City University of New York |page=92}}</ref><ref name='SorS'>{{cite book |author1=[[Catherine Johns|Johns, C.]] |date=1982 |title=Sex or Symbol? Erotic Images of Greece and Rome |publisher=British Museum Press |place=London}}</ref><ref name='TRAC'>{{Cite book |author1=Parker, A. |date=2018 |chapter=The Bells! The Bells! Approaching ''tintinnabula'' in Roman Britain and Beyond |editor1=Parker, A. |editor2=Mckie, S. |title=Material Approaches to Roman Magic: Occult Objects and Supernatural Substances |series=[[Theoretical Roman Archaeology Conference|TRAC]] Themes in Roman Archaeology 2 |place=Oxford |publisher=Oxbow |pages=57–68}}</ref> ''Fascinus'' was thought particularly to ward off evil from children, mainly boys, and from conquering generals. The protective function of the phallus is usually related to the virile and regenerative powers of an erected phallus, though in most cases the emotion, shame, or laughter created by obscenity is the power that diverts the evil eye.<ref name='Dasen'>{{cite book |author1=Dasen, V. |date=2015 |chapter=Pobaskania: Amulets and Magic in Antiquity |editor1=Boschung, D. |editor2=Bremmer, J. N. |title=The Materiality of Magic |series=Morphomata 20 |pages= 177–204}}</ref>
There are very few Roman images of people wearing a phallic charm.<ref name='Dasen' /> Varro notes the custom of hanging a phallic charm on a baby's neck,{{efn|Varro, ''On the Latin language'', VII.97}} and examples have been found of phallus-bearing rings too small to be worn except by children.<ref name='Henig'>Martin Henig, ''Religion in Roman Britain'' (London: BT Batsford LTD, 1984), pp. 185–186 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZOhxSp8nlPsC&pg=PA186&dq=%22A+child's+gold+ring+with+phallus%22&hl=en&ei=1tOTTIXKG4TfnAenpYCRCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22A%20child's%20gold%20ring%20with%20phallus%22&f=false online], with image of example.</ref> A 2017 [[experimental archaeology]] project suggested that some types of phallic pendant were designed to remain pointing outwards, in the direction of travel of the wearer, in order to face towards any potential danger or bad luck and nullify it before it could affect the wearer.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Whitmore, A. |date=2017 |chapter=Fascinating ''fascina'': apotropaic magic and how to wear a penis |editor1=Cifarelli, M. |editor2=Gawlinkski, L. |title=What shall I say of clothes? Theoretical and Methodological Approaches to the Study of Dress in Antiquity |place=Boston, MA |publisher=[[American Institute of Archaeology]] |pages=47–65}}</ref> Other symbols may have been interchangeable with the phallus, such as the club of [[Hercules]].<ref name='Dasen' />
The victory of the phallus over the power of the evil eye may be represented by the phallus ejaculating towards a disembodied eye. This motif is shown in several examples of Roman art.<ref>Daniel Ogden, ''Magic, Witchcraft, and Ghosts in the Greek and Roman Worlds: A Sourcebook'' (Oxford University Press, 2002), p. 225 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ox3QRxWQQtcC&pg=PA225&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=6#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false online.]</ref> For example, the motif is known from multiple [[relief|relief sculptures]] from [[Leptis Magna]] in present-day [[Libya]],<ref name='SorS' /> as well as several instances on [[Hadrian's Wall]].<ref name='BAR'>{{cite book |author1=Parker, A. |date=2017 |chapter=Protecting the Troops? Phallic Carvings in the North of Roman Britain |editor1=Parker, A |title=''Ad Vallum'': Papers on the Roman Army and Frontiers in celebration of Dr [[Brian Dobson (archaeologist)|Brian Dobson]] |series=BAR British Series 631 |place=Oxford |publisher=British Archaeological Report |pages=117–130}}</ref> A 1st-century BC [[terracotta]] figurine shows "two little phallus-men sawing an eyeball in half."<ref name='CAW' /><ref name='SorS' />
The "fist and phallus" amulet was prevalent amongst soldiers. These are phallic pendants with a representation of a (usually) clenched fist at the bottom of the shaft, facing away from the [[glans]]. Several examples show the fist making the ''manus fica'' or "[[fig sign]]", a symbol of good luck.<ref name='Henig' /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/LIN-2BE126 |publisher=Portable Antiquities Scheme |title=PAS Record: LIN-2BE126 |accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> The largest known collection comes from [[Camulodunum]].<ref>{{cite book |author1=Crummy, N. |title=Colchester Archaeological Report 2: The Roman Small finds from excavations in Colchester 1971-9 |place=Colchester |publisher=Colchester Archaeological Trust |date=1983}}</ref> Some examples of the fist-and-phallus amulets incorporate [[vulva]]te imagery as well as an extra [[Apotropaic magic|apotropaic]] device.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Parker, A. |date=2015 |title=The Fist-and-Phallus Pendants from Roman Catterick |journal=Britannia |volume=46 |pages=135–149 |doi=10.1017/S0068113X15000161}}</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px"> File:Tintinnabulum-Fund in Herculaneum.jpg|A ''[[Tintinnabulum (Ancient Rome)|tintinnabulum]]'' from [[Herculaneum]] (Italy), with the phallus as a beast which the human male engages in combat. File:Bas-relief of fascinus.jpg|Bas-relief of a legged phallus ejaculating into an [[evil eye]] on which a scorpion sits, from [[Leptis Magna]] (Libya). File:Yorkshire Museum, York (Eboracum) (7685630354).jpg|A simple phallic relief from ''[[Eboracum]]'' (York, UK). File:KENT-E3D152 (FindID 392891).jpg|A phallic pendant from Kent (UK). File:Roman_phallic_pendant_(FindID_156232).jpg|A simple phallic pendant from Suffolk (UK). </gallery>

'''''Filthy Rich and Homeless''''' is a [[Logie Award]]-winning Australian TV documentary series produced by Blackfella Films and broadcast in 2017 (Season 1) and 2018 (Season 2) on [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]].
The series follows five wealthy Australians who swap their life of privilege for homelessness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blackfellafilms.com.au/project/filthy-rich-homeless/|title=FILTHY RICH & HOMELESS - Blackfella Films|website=blackfellafilms.com.au}}</ref>
==Season 1== The five participants were self-made millionaire Tim Guest; Kayla Fenech, daughter of boxing champion [[Jeff Fenech]]; rags to riches beauty entrepreneur Jellaine Dee; third generation pub baron Stu Laundy; and model and Sydney socialite Christian Wilkins, son of television presenter [[Richard Wilkins (TV presenter)|Richard Wilkins]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://tvtonight.com.au/2017/05/airdate-filthy-rich-and-homeless.html|title=Airdate: Filthy Rich and Homeless|date=29 May 2017|publisher=[[TV Tonight]]}}</ref>
==Season 2== The five participants were socialite Skye Leckie, wife of media company executive director [[David Leckie]]; actor-broadcaster [[Cameron Daddo]]; author [[Benjamin Law (writer)|Benjamin Law]]; politician and activist [[Alex Greenwich]]; and Instagram star Alli Simpson.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/socialite-skye-leckie-does-it-tough-in-sbs-homelessness-docuseries-20180705-p4zpqj.html|title=Socialite Skye Leckie does it tough in SBS homelessness docuseries|first=Karl|last=Quinn|date=7 July 2018|website=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>

{{Infobox ethnic group | group = Finnish Canadians
{{small|''Kanadansuomalaiset, Kanadafinländare''
''}} | image = | pop = '''136,215'''
(by ancestry, [[Canada 2011 Census|2011 Census]]){{cite web |url=http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/nhs-enm/2011/dp-pd/dt-td/Rp-eng.cfm?TABID=2&LANG=E&APATH=3&DETAIL=0&DIM=0&FL=A&FREE=0&GC=0&GID=1118296&GK=0&GRP=0&PID=105396&PRID=0&PTYPE=105277&S=0&SHOWALL=0&SUB=0&Temporal=2013&THEME=95&VID=0&VNAMEE=&VNAMEF=&D1=0&D2=0&D3=0&D4=0&D5=0&D6=0 |author=[[Statistics Canada]] |title=2011 National Household Survey: Data tables |accessdate=11 February 2014}}
{{small|'''0.4% of the Canadian population'''}} | popplace = {{hlist| [[Toronto]] | [[Thunder Bay]] | [[Greater Sudbury]] | [[Vancouver]] }} | region1 = {{flag|Ontario}} | pop1 = 74,505 | ref1 = | region2 = {{flag|British Columbia}} | pop2 = 31,610 | ref2 = | region3 = {{flag|Alberta}} | pop3 = 16,285 | ref3 = | langs = {{hlist| [[Canadian English]] | [[Finnish language|Finnish]] | [[Canadian French]] }} | rels = {{hlist| [[Christianity]] ([[Lutheranism]], [[Protestantism]])}} | related = [[Finnish Americans]], [[Estonian Canadian]]s }} '''Finnish Canadians''' are [[Canadians|Canadian citizens]] of [[Finns|Finnish]] ancestry or [[Finns]] who emigrated to and reside in [[Canada]]. According to the 2001 census number over 131,040 Canadians claim Finnish ancestry. [[Finns]] started coming to Canada in the early 1880s, and in much larger numbers in the early 20th century and well into the mid-20th century. Finnish [[immigration]] to Canada was often a direct result of [[economic depression]]s and wars, or in the aftermath of major conflicts like the [[Finnish Civil War]].{{Cite web | last = Adamson | first = Julia | title = - SGW - Finnish Saskatchewan Genealogy Roots | work = Saskatchewan History and Ethnic Roots | publisher = Saskatchewan Gen Web Project | date = 14 Mar 2010 | url = http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~cansk/Saskatchewan/ethnic/finnish-saskatchewan.html | accessdate = 2010-12-07 }}{{Citation | last = Johnson | first = Gilbert | title = Saskatchewan History | place = University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan | publisher = Saskatchewan Archives Board | year = 1962 | volume = XV Spring 1962 Number 2 | chapter = Prairie People "The New Finland Colony". | format = digitised online 30-Nov-2010 with permission from Saskatchewan Archivist by the New Finland Historical and Heritage Society, Julia Adamson | page = 69 | url = http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~cansk/Finnish/NewFinlandDistrict-GJohnson.html }} Canada was often chosen as a final destination because of the similarity in [[climate]] and natural conditions, while [[employment]] in [[logging]] or [[homesteading]] attracted landless farmers in the early 20th century.{{Citation | last = Cleef | first = Eugene Van | title = Finnish Settlement in Canada | publisher = The Geographical Review 1952, p. 253-266. | year = 1952 | url = http://www.genealogia.fi/emi/art/article156e.htm | pages = 253–266 | format = republished online genealogia, The Genealogical Society of Finland | accessdate = 2010-10-07}} Migratory movements of Finns between Canada and the United States was very common as well.{{Citation | last = Wishart | first = David J | title = Encyclopedia of the Great Plains | publisher = U of Nebraska Press | year = 2004 | edition = illustrated, annotated | pages = 230 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rtRFyFO4hpEC&pg=PA230&lpg=PA230&dq=new+finland+district+saskatchewan&source=bl&ots=IhFTzjxNXo&sig=HCeUcRi9Ygqbd427Bj_mTA4CiBI&hl=en&ei=hMr_TMC5K8KhnAfplrGlCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=new%20finland%20&f=false | isbn = 978-0-8032-4787-1 | id = {{ISBN|0-8032-4787-7}} }} In the early 20th century, newly arrived Finnish immigrants to Canada quickly became involved in political organizations, churches, athletic clubs and other forms of associational life.{{Cite web | last = Gallop | first = Ralph | title = History of New Finland Colony covers 72 years of progress | publisher = Wapella Post, now The World-Spectator | format = digitised online October 25, 2009 by the New Finland Historical and Heritage Society, Red Lauttamus and Julia Adamson | year = 1972 | url = http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~cansk/school/Red/NewFinlandPage5.html | accessdate = 2010-12-08}}{{Cite web | last = Anderson | first = Alan | title = Finnish settlements | work = Canadian Plains Research Center, University of Regina | publisher = Encyclopedia of Saskatchewan | year = 2006 | url = http://esask.uregina.ca/entry/finnish_settlements.html | accessdate = 2010-12-07 }} Halls and co-operatives were often erected in communities with sizable Finnish populations. "Finnish Canadians" pioneered efforts to establish [[co-operatives]] in several Canadian cities. Canada's largest co-operative, the [[Consumers' Co-operative Society]], was started by Finns. The [[Canada 2011 Census|2011 Census]] recorded 136,215 Canadians who claimed Finnish ancestry, an increase compared to the 2006 Census.[http://www12.statcan.ca/census-recensement/2006/dp-pd/hlt/97-562/pages/page.cfm?Lang=E&Geo=PR&Code=01&Table=2&Data=Count&StartRec=1&Sort=3&Display=All&CSDFilter=5000] == History == The earliest Finnish immigrants to Canada came from the US, possibly as early as 1820's for the construction of the [[Welland Canal]]. The [[Canadian Pacific Railway]] recruited immigrants directly from Finland in the late 1800s.{{cite journal|last=Lindström-Best|first=Varpu|title=Geographical perspectives on Finnish Canadian immigration and settlement|journal=Polyphony|date=Fall 1981|volume=3|issue=2|page=16|url=http://www.ourfutureourpast.ca/loc_hist/page.aspx?id=3763469|accessdate=9 August 2013}} Canadians of Finnish ancestry often formed a large percentage of left-wing organizations during the early 1900s, as Finland had, by 1906 as a part of the Russian empire, already become one of the first nations to adopt [[universal suffrage]]. Up until the early 1940s, the so-called "Red Finns," who held deep socialist convictions, far outnumbered "White Finns," the more religious and conservative Finns. This was partially due to the number of political refugees escaping persecution after the [[Finnish Civil War]], but also attributable to the response of several, formerly apolitical Finns from rural [[Ostrobothnia (region)|Ostrobothnia]], to harsh economic conditions. Finnish Canadians with Marxist political views aligned themselves with the [[Social Democratic Party of Canada]] and later, with the [[Communist Party of Canada]], centered around the newspaper ''[[Vapaus]]'' (Freedom). Many Finns, however, were distrustful of politicians as a result of the perceived failure and reformism of the Finnish Social Democratic Party during the general strike in November 1917 and the reformist policy the party adopted after the Civil War. Finns arriving in Canada who had already faced severe class conflict and repression would line-up with the radical union, the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW) emphasizing anti-authoritarianism and anti-statism. The IWW would hold considerable influence in the mines and logging camps of Northern Ontario. A decline in the Finnish-Canadian population began with the exodus 2000-3000{{cite book|last=Karni|first=Michael G|title=Finnish diaspora I : Canada, South America, Africa, Australia and Sweden|year=1981|publisher=Multicultural History Society of Ontario|location=Toronto|isbn=0-919045-08-1|page=203|url=http://www.ourfutureourpast.ca/loc_hist/page.aspx?id=3765510}} skilled workers and loggers to [[Republic of Karelia|Soviet Karelia]] in the 1920s and 30s, and the large number of Finnish-Canadian volunteers in the [[Spanish Civil War]]. Finnish-Canadians, along with Ukrainians, formed the largest section of volunteers in the Canadian contingent of the [[International Brigades]], [[Mackenzie-Papineau Battalion]]. Finns formed the Mackenzie-Papineau Battalions "Ilkka" machine-gun company. The period after the 1930s marks a decline in Finnish co-operative activity in Canada. Canada started seeing a drastic increase in immigration from Finland during the late 1920s and forward, as the United States [[Immigration Act of 1924]] did not consider Finland to be among the Western European favourable countries to have immigration from, resulting in a strong restriction of 500 Finnish immigrants per year to the US.John Powell, "Encyclopedia of North American immigration", p. 99 | When passage of the restrictive Johnson-Reed act in 1924 drastically cut the Finnish quota, Finns increasingly turned their attention to Canada. Despite conservative "White" Finnish support for Nazi Germany during World War II, Canadian immigration policy in the 1940s favoured admitting "White Finns" to Canada. This, combined with a fiercely anti-socialist view in the post-World War II era, led to a shift in the political balance of the Finnish-Canadian community. == Demographic concentrations == [[File:Thunder Bay skyline.JPG|thumb|250px|[[Thunder Bay|Thunder Bay, Ontario]] is home to 14,510 people of Finnish descent, the highest concentration of Finnish Canadians [[per capita]] in the country,[http://www12.statcan.gc.ca/english/census06/data/profiles/release/RetrieveProductTable.cfm?Temporal=2006&APATH=3&PID=92631&THEME=80&PTYPE=89103&VID=0&GK=NA&GC=99&FL=0&RL=0&FREE=0&METH=0&S=1 Profile of Ethnic Origin and Visible Minorities for Census Metropolitan Areas and Census Agglomerations, 2006 Census]. [[Statistics Canada]]. Retrieved 13 March 2009. and the second largest Finnish population in Canada after [[Toronto]] which has 14,750 persons of Finnish origin.]] [[Central Canada]] (mainly Ontario) has generally been the largest destination for Finns, followed by British Columbia, recording 72,990 (ON) and 29,875 (BC) Finns in 2006. Several small rural Finnish communities were established in [[Alberta]] and [[Saskatchewan]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/finns/ |title=Finns |author=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] |accessdate=14 February 2014}} Today, the communities of [[Thunder Bay]], [[Greater Sudbury|Sudbury]] and [[New Finland, Saskatchewan|New Finland]] form the main centres of Finnish-Canadian activity. Thunder Bay boasts the largest Finnish population outside of [[Fennoscandia]]{{Citation needed|date=January 2015}}, and the only Finnish cultural centre in Canada, housed in the [[Finnish Labour Temple]] along with [[the Hoito]] Restaurant. The Finnish-Canadian weeklies ''[[Canadan Sanomat]]'' and ''[[Vapaa Sana]]'' publish out of Thunder Bay and Toronto respectively. Another significant Finnish-Canadian newspaper, ''[[Vapaus]]'', was published in Sudbury from 1917 to 1974. Other prominent communities are [[Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario|Sault Ste. Marie]], [[Kirkland Lake]] and [[Timmins]], in Ontario. === Finnish Canadians by province or territory === Finnish Canadian population by province and territory in Canada in 2011: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! [[Provinces and territories of Canada|Province or territory]] !! Finnish Canadians !! Percentage |- |style="background:silver" | '''{{flag|Canada}}''' || style="background:silver" | 136,215 || style="background:silver" | 0.4% |- | {{flag|Ontario}} || 74,505 || |- | {{flag|British Columbia}} || 31,610 || |- | {{flag|Alberta}} || 16,285 || |- | {{flag|Saskatchewan}} || 4,470 || |- | {{flag|Manitoba}} || 3,850 || |- | {{flag|Quebec}} || 2,725 || |- | {{flag|Nova Scotia}} || 1,115 || |- | {{flag|New Brunswick}} || 710 || |- | {{flag|Yukon}} || 435 || |- | {{flag|Newfoundland and Labrador}} || 225 || |- | {{flag|Prince Edward Island}} || 160 || |- | {{flag|Northwest Territories}} || 100 || |- | {{flag|Nunavut}} || 25 || |} ==Notable Finnish Canadians== * [[Pamela Anderson]], actress * [[Randy Carlyle]], [[National Hockey League]] player and former head coach of the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] * [[Judy Erola]], politician and businesswoman * [[Stuart Immonen]], comic book and sketch artist * Afie Jurvanen - aka [[Bahamas (musician)]], musician; won a [[Juno award]] in 2015 for Songwriter of the Year and Adult Alternative Album of the Year * [[Sanna Kannasto]], activist and feminist * [[Joe Keithley]], punk rock musician * [[Matti Kurikka]], utopian socialist; led the short-lived experimental utopian community of [[Sointula, British Columbia]] * [[Larissa Loyva]], singer-songwriter * [[Pentti Lund]], National Hockey League player and [[Calder Memorial Trophy]] winner * [[Michael Mahonen]], actor * [[Chico Maki]], ice hockey player * [[Kate Maki]], singer-songwriter * [[Wayne Maki]], ice hockey player * [[Sarah Manninen]], actress * [[Peter Nygård]], founder and CEO of [[Nygård International]] * [[Kalervo Oberg]], anthropologist * [[Chris Pronger]], National Hockey League player; has won [[Hart Memorial Trophy]], [[Stanley Cup]] and two Olympic gold medals * [[Rosvall and Voutilainen]], labour activists * [[Sonya Salomaa]], actress and model * [[Ray Timgren]], National Hockey League player; has won two [[Stanley Cup]] wins with the Toronto Maple Leafs * [[Tyler Varga]], NFL player * [[Jake Virtanen]], ice hockey player * Gayle Christie (Ingle), Mayor of York * ==See also== {{Portal|Canada|Finland}} *[[Canada–Finland relations]] *[[Finnish diaspora]] *[[Finnish Americans]] *[[Finglish]] *[[Scandinavian Canadians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100426062932/http://www.multiculturalcanada.ca/vapaus2500 Multicultural Canada website] digitized issues of the Sudbury, Ontario newspaper Vapaus (Liberty), 1921–1930 and 1948–1974 * {{cite book|last=Schaefer|first=Ewald|title=The Finnish Canadian collection|year=1986|publisher=Multicultural History Society of Ontario|location=Toronto|url=http://www.ourroots.ca/e/toc.aspx?id=9248}} {{People of Canada}} {{Finnish diaspora}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Canadians Of Finnish Ancestry}} [[Category:European Canadian|Finnish]] [[Category:Finnish Canadian| ]] [[Category:Canadian people of Finnish descent|*]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Canada|Finnish]]

{{cleanup|reason=redundant footnotes -- can be consolidated.|date=March 2017}} {{multiple image | caption_align= left | header_align=center | align = right | direction = vertical | width = thumb | header = | image1 = Boston corner shop.jpg | alt1 = A corner shop | caption1 = A typical urban [[corner shop]]. All the food visible is relatively imperishable: dried, processed and tinned products, which may have a low vitamin and nutritional content compared to fresher produce. Shown below is a vegetable counter of a larger supermarket. | image2 = VegetablesSupermarket.jpg | alt2 = Vegetables at a supermarket | caption2 = }} A '''food desert''' is an area, especially one with low-income residents, that has limited access to affordable and nutritious food.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://americannutritionassociation.org/|title=The Community for Science-Based Nutrition {{!}} American Nutrition Association|website=americannutritionassociation.org|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Story|first=Mary|last2=Kaphingst|first2=Karen M.|last3=Robinson-O'Brien|first3=Ramona|last4=Glanz|first4=Karen|date=2008|title=Creating healthy food and eating environments: policy and environmental approaches|journal=Annual Review of Public Health|volume=29|pages=253–272|doi=10.1146/annurev.publhealth.29.020907.090926|issn=0163-7525|pmid=18031223}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/BILLS-110hr6124eh/pdf/BILLS-110hr6124eh.pdf|title=Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008, 110th Cong, 2nd Sess, HR 6124, Title VII|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 17, 2017}}</ref> In contrast, an area with supermarkets or vegetable shops is a [[food oasis]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.doh.wa.gov/CommunityandEnvironment/Food/AccesstoHealthyFoods/FoodOasis|title=Food Oasis :: Washington State Department of Health}}</ref> The designation considers the type and quality of food available to the population, in addition to the number, nature, and size of food stores that are accessible.<ref name="Coveney & O'Dwyer 2009">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.healthplace.2008.01.010 |pmid=18396090 |title=Effects of mobility and location on food access |journal=Health & Place |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=45–55 |year=2009 |last1=Coveney |first1=John |last2=O'Dwyer |first2=Lisel A }}</ref> Food deserts are characterized by a lack of supermarkets which decreases residents' access to fruits, vegetables and other whole foods.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://sojo.net/magazine/april-2017/grocery-store-inequity|title=Grocery Store Inequity|last=Lee|first=Courtney Hall|date=2017-02-23|work=Sojourners|access-date=2017-11-17}}</ref>
